body: When the news broke on Thursday of a freakish traffic accident that injured several people at the Chanukah Wonderland workshop run by the Lubavitch community of Woodmere, on Long Island, the story was picked up by the usual suspects: Newsday, The Daily News, The New York Post and The Associated Press. It also happened to be that day's top North
title: If It Involves Jews, Chabad's Tiny but Far-Flung News Organization Is on It

body: Along Linden Boulevard in East New York, the officers of Operation Impact patrol the Pink Houses with all the rigor of a military patrol, a clannish band of partners whose uniforms shout authority even when they do not speak. They tread the maze of eight-story buildings, inspect the interior staircases, aim their flashlights into the nighttime
title: A Special Effort in Tough Precincts Makes Inroads Against Crime

body: After a juror fell ill and said she could not continue deliberating, a judge in Brooklyn declared a mistrial on Monday in the case of Lee Woods, one of three men charged with the killing of Officer Russel Timoshenko during a traffic stop last year. The juror, a woman in her 20s, complained of heart trouble last week, and visited a cardiologist over
title: Mistrial for Man Charged With Killing Police Officer

body: THE grand opening of the Newseum's new building in Washington last spring was upbeat and festive. A trained eagle flew across the sky. Confetti cannons shot colorful flakes toward the clouds. A block party on Pennsylvania Avenue continued inside with speeches by luminaries like the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, and John G. Roberts Jr., chief justice
title: Museum Growth Meets Hard Times

body: CROWN HEIGHTS, Brooklyn, a mash-up of cultures, is home to both the annual West Indian American parade and the headquarters of the Chabad-Lubavitch Hasidim. Adding an upscale bar and beer garden to the mix might seem counterintuitive. ''Everyone thought we were crazy,'' said Anatoly Dubinsky, recalling the reaction last April when he opened
title: BOÎTE; An Already Eclectic Mix Gets an Upscale Bar

body: Punk is not dead, though these days on the Bowery it's a whole lot quieter. Silent, even. Every week, dozens of people, usually young and artfully scruffy, climb three creaky flights of stairs off this formerly gritty stretch of downtown Manhattan, a block from where CBGB, the hallowed hall of punk, once stood. Often shrouded in hoodies, inked with
title: BOWERY JOURNAL; A Place to Mellow Out, Without Losing Your Edge

body: Years ago, during the darkest days of her life, Valerie Andrews would rather have been dead. ''It was like, I didn't want to feel anything,'' Ms. Andrews said. ''I just went off the deep end. I was a lost soul.'' It would have been better to die, she recalls thinking, than to live as she did, only for a high. She spent years on the streets of her
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; After a Lifetime on the Streets, a New Road to Travel

body: the nub of a debate sparked in May by sweeping labor abuse charges against the Orthodox Jewish owners of the largest kosher meatpacking plant in the nation -- was pondered Tuesday night in a panel discussion at Yeshiva University in Upper Manhattan, the academic nexus of Orthodox Judaism. It was, for the most part, a subdued and scholarly
title: Label Says Kosher; Ethics Suggest Otherwise

body: LEARNING that Plaxico Burress had put a bullet in his right leg came as a blow to many New Yorkers, especially because acrobatic catches from the Giants wide receiver had helped to propel their team to the Super Bowl championship. But an equally if not more perplexing discovery for some was the venue where the unfortunate and surely painful shot
title: With One Shot, A Club Is Notorious

body: A 20-year-old man has been charged with murder in the stabbing death of a New York City bus driver, the police said on Tuesday. The man, Horace D. Moore, of 1327 Park Place in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, told the police that he stabbed the driver, Edwin Thomas, 46, on Monday after an argument on the bus, said the chief police spokesman, Paul J.
title: Crown Heights Man Is Charged With Bus Driver's Murder

body: With sheet music resting near her pillow, Nia Drummond, 14, hovers over a keyboard set on a floral comforter. Singing ''New York State of Mind,'' the teenager's powerful voice echoes off the bare walls, filling the sparsely furnished two-bedroom apartment in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, where she has lived her entire life. From the doorway, Andrea
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Fresh Start for a Teenager Who Wants to Be Heard

body: A somber Israel on Tuesday buried six victims of last week's terrorist attack on a Jewish outreach center in Mumbai, India. Two of the victims, Rabbi Gavriel Holtzberg, 29, and his wife, Rivka, 28, were serving as emissaries in India for the Hasidic Chabad-Lubavitch movement when they were killed. They were buried side by side after dark in the
title: Orphaned Boy Is Focus At Hostages' Funeral

body: An article on Friday about Rabbi Gavriel and Rivka Holtzberg, a couple from Brooklyn taken hostage when the Jewish center they ran in Mumbai, India, was seized by terrorist gunmen, who later killed them, referred incorrectly to the women swaying on their knees in a room at the world headquarters of the Lubavitch Hasidic movement in Crown Heights,
title: Corrections

body: International CHINA'S ECONOMY SLOWS DOWN And Turns to Its Thrifty Millions It might be up to the frugal to rescue China. China's economy, once the fastest growing in the world, has slowed down alarmingly fast. Projections by the World Bank and other financial institutions have been revised downward, and China is looking to its legion of consumers,
title: INSIDE THE TIMES: December 3, 2008

body: A New York City bus driver was fatally stabbed in Brooklyn on Monday after refusing to give a transfer to his assailant, who had not paid his fare, the police said. Witnesses said the killer jumped off the bus, slipped the hood of his black sweatshirt over his head and ran away. New York City Transit officials said it was the first slaying of a
title: Rider Fatally Stabs City Bus Driver and Flees

body: For many Jews, they are homes away from home: Chabad Houses, welcoming outposts in foreign lands or across the United States, places to drop in to celebrate Hanukkah, Passover or weekly Shabbat dinners. Almost always, the Chabad Houses are run by young couples, emissaries of the Chabad-Lubavitch denomination, a Hasidic faith with its headquarters
title: Vowing to Continue Work Of Couple Killed in Attack

body: Leaders of the Chabad-Lubavitch movement in Brooklyn and the worldwide ultra-orthodox Jewish community began on Friday to mourn the deaths of Rabbi Gavriel Holtzberg and his wife Rivka, who were killed in the terrorist attack of the Nariman House, the Jewish outreach center in Mumbai that the young couple had left New York to manage in 2003. Rabbi
title: Brooklyn Couple Killed in Attacks

body: Hours before the sun came up on a cool October morning in 2006, people living near the Dakota Stables on the Upper West Side were suddenly awakened by the sound of a jackhammer. Soon word spread that a demolition crew was hacking away at the brick cornices of the stables, an 1894 Romanesque Revival building, on Amsterdam Avenue at 77th Street, that
title: PRESERVING THE CITY; Preservationists See Bulldozers Charging Through a Loophole

body: In 2003, barely out of their teens and newly married, Rabbi Gavriel Holtzberg and his wife, Rivka, moved from Brooklyn to the coastal city of Mumbai, India, to manage a mix of educational center, synagogue and social hall known as a Chabad house, one of about 3,500 outposts around the world run by the Lubavitch Hasidic movement. The place soon
title: Brooklyn Couple Missing in Attacks

body: The fire burned so hot that it melted a smoke detector, dripping molten plastic through Lt. Robert J. Ryan's fire jacket and across his neck and shoulders. It was the kind of injury that could have tempted others to leave the Fire Department, but he chose to stay, spending a year recuperating, and returning to work in 2007 with twisted pink scars
title: Firefighter Severely Burned in '06 Dies in Staten Island Blaze

body: FOR CHILDREN 'ADVENTURES OF THE PUPPET PRINCESS' (Saturday and Sunday) Can a puppet show really mollify a witch? Written and directed by Jennifer Goodlander, the show focuses on Putu, a tomboy, who is lost in the jungle with
title: Spare Times

body: FOR CHILDREN KIDROCKERS FALL ROCKSTIVAL It's hard to imagine mature, self-respecting childless adults wanting -- much less needing -- to sneak into a kids' show. But Beth Lorge has met such desperate grown-ups. ''People blog, 'Has anyone got a kid I can borrow?' '' she said. That's because unaccompanied adults are not allowed into the concerts Ms.
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: The city will reduce funds for 21 day care sites in January as part of efforts to close a yawning budget deficit, city officials said on Wednesday. While officials made it clear that the sites would not be closed, critics charged that the reductions would have the same effect, by destabilizing the centers to the point that they would be forced to
title: City Plans to Reduce Aid To 21 Day Care Locations

body: Some would-be robbers picked the wrong shop owner to rob in Brooklyn on Monday night. Even though he was unarmed, the shop owner, identified by neighbors as Youssouf Drame, 35, wrested a gun away from one of the men and fatally shot two of them. The police say that two other suspects -- it's unclear whether they entered the store -- are at large.
title: Unarmed, Shop Owner Turned Tables on Gunmen

body: IN his relationships with women, the hip-hop writer and actor Danny Hoch often finds himself playing the role of the exotic native New Yorker to girlfriends who hail from other parts of the country. ''How many girlfriends have said to me: 'Oh, say ''coffee.'' Say it. It's so sexy'?'' Mr. Hoch said the other day with a laugh, putting a New York spin
title: Assault on the Gentrifiers, and the Audience

body: LIKE many others, the Zimbabwean-born dancer and choreographer Nora Chipaumire did not get much sleep on election night. As she watched Barack Obama's victory speech, fielded exultant calls from Kenya and soaked up the jubilant noise in her Brooklyn neighborhood (Crown Heights, where, she said, some good citizens had taken it ''upon themselves to
title: DANCE; Brooklyn and Senegal, Talking Across Cultures

body: New York City's antiquated voting system buckled, groaned and occasionally even gave way on Tuesday as millions of people thronged the polls to cast votes in the presidential election. Persistent problems from past elections -- broken machines, long waits and confusion among poll workers -- were made even worse, voters and election observers said,
title: Big Turnout Means Lines For Voters Across City

They won't have engines, passengers or pilots, and they may travel only a matter of feet. Still, they are designed to
title: Spare Times: For Children

title: Spare Times

author: Susan Hartman is the author of two books of poetry, ''Dumb Show'' and ''El Abogado.''
body: TWENTY years ago, six girls lit up a troubled Brooklyn block. Gunfire could be heard in the distance. There was a stream of visitors to the apartments of drug dealers. title: The Jump Rope Girls, 20 Years On

body: A federal judge on Friday upheld New York City's policy prohibiting public school teachers from wearing political buttons in the classroom, but said the teachers could place campaign material into colleagues' mailboxes and hang posters on bulletin boards maintained by their union, as long as they were in areas off-limits to students. The split
title: Judge Says No to Teachers' Campaign Buttons, but Yes to Certain Politicking

body: ZOMBIECON There are still two weeks until Halloween, and already the undead are out in force. ZombieCon, the annual parade of the bloody, the battered and the strangely animated, takes place on Saturday. For the fourth year participants in this loosely organized spectacle will roam the streets of Manhattan (above), dressed in their best
title: Spare Times

body: If confession is good for the soul, it's even more healing when it occurs after more than 60 years and some 3,000 miles from the site of the dastardly deeds. title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES; An Ebbets Field Confession From That 'Brennan' Kid

body: On a recent day on the boulevard that stretches from the heart of Brooklyn to the sea, a young teacher helped his daughters with schoolwork, a man hurled Russian insults and coins at an elderly woman who he thought was driving too slowly, and a man from Bedford-Stuyvesant read a tabloid for hours, having only just discovered, after 46 years, the
title: BROOKLYN JOURNAL; A Tree-Lined Boulevard That's a Park and a Living Room

body: Last week before Rosh Hashana, Rabbi Shea Hecht of Crown Heights, Brooklyn, said he was bombarded with hundreds of e-mail messages, phone calls, faxes and letters within a short time, one of them threatening. In general, the messages protested the tradition of kaparot -- sometimes spelled kapparot or kapparos -- in which Orthodox Jews take live
title: Dead Chickens, Amends, and an Outcry

body: The first and hardest part was deciding which crop to take to market from the farm in Red Hook, Brooklyn. All arguments were charged with the stainless-steel passion of 15-year-olds. title: ABOUT NEW YORK; Sweat Equity Put to Use Within Sight of Wall St.

title: Name by Name, a Push To Change Drug Laws

body: A teenage girl was arrested on Wednesday in the fatal stabbing of her 16-year-old cousin in her family's apartment in Crown Heights the day before, the authorities said. title: Cousin Is Charged In Brooklyn Death

body: A 16-year-old girl was found stabbed to death Tuesday night in her family's apartment in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, the police said. When she tried to open the door, the path
title: Girl, 16, Is Fatally Stabbed At Her Home in Brooklyn

body: FOR years, Adam Frank yearned for a brownstone of his own. In 2002, after living in a series of rentals in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, he almost bought one for $575,000. It was a three-family brownstone on South Second Street. ''It was in need of a major overhaul,'' he said. After the inspection, ''I freaked out and had trouble getting financing. I was
title: THE HUNT; A 'Goldilocks' House

body: Underwater Trains Q.Given the price of scrap metal, why is the Metropolitan Transportation Authority placing its obsolete cars in artificial reefs instead of scrapping them? A. title: F. Y. I.

title: MUSEUM REVIEW; Kids, Can You Say 'Cultural Diversity'?

title: Inside Big Yellow

body: ''GO one stop on the express, change for the local and get on at the back of the train.'' title: NEW YORK OBSERVED; Along the Tracks of Her Mind

title: Brooklyn Woman Was Killed During Botched Robbery

title: A Carnival Approaches, and the Sequins Fly

body: MILLIONS of New Yorkers compress their lives into small spaces and yearn for things that their friends in the suburbs don't think twice about: an extra bedroom, a patch of grass, a little distance between themselves and the neighbors. Circle the block five times looking for a place to park, and another wish can be added to the list: a private
title: The Ultimate Luxury: A Garage

title: Lengthen City Term Limits? No Way, Challengers Say

body: An article and a picture caption in some editions last Tuesday about the search for a man who had attacked and robbed at least 10 people in Brooklyn misidentified the neighborhood where his latest attack occurred, in the elevator of an apartment building. It is in Crown Heights, not Flatbush.
title: Corrections

body: Detective Matthew Walker was sitting on his couch watching television recently when he saw surveillance video on the news of a man attacking an elderly woman from behind as she got off an elevator. The video, viewed by many people on the Internet and television since the police released it on Monday, has provoked widespread outrage. But for
title: Video of Attack In Brooklyn Leads to Arrest

body: FOR CHILDREN The Battle of Brooklyn Revisited Battles still rage in Brooklyn, though the issues are more likely to concern real estate than rebellion, and the weapons don't include cannonballs and muskets. But they did 232 years ago, when Washington's troops faced British soldiers in the Revolutionary War's largest battle. That was on Aug. 27,
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: By now, thousands of people have seen the mugging of Lilian France. They have watched the surveillance video of the stranger in the cap choking her from behind, and then stealing Ms. France's purse -- and her cane -- when she collapsed. On television and countless Web sites, the video, perfectly framed and crystal clear, has provoked widespread
title: As Manhunt Intensifies, Victim Tries to Recall Attack

body: The security camera inside the elevator captured it all: a vicious choke hold, an older woman's flailing arms and then her limp body sprawled on the floor as her attacker ran off with her purse. title: Video Shows An Attack In Brooklyn

body: The skies over Coney Island put on a spectacular show on Saturday evening, with the sunset casting violet hues and a fat yellow moon disappearing and reappearing through clouds. title: CONEY ISLAND JOURNAL; Roller Skaters Revel in a New Rink in the City

body: Baba Diouf, a Harlem shopkeeper, has carved a living out of a single penny, snatched in broad daylight from a competitor's discount store in a fiendish scheme to lure business a few yards north on Frederick Douglass Boulevard. The competitor's store was called New Futa 99 Plus. The sign Mr. Diouf hung outside his new store read Bab's 98-cent Plus
title: The Cost of Retail Survival in New York: 99. Or Is It 98?

body: FIVE years ago, several hundred members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints and six funeral directors arrived at Bayside Cemetery in Ozone Park, Queens, to take part in an ambitious project. title: OZONE PARK; Weeds Among the Graves, and Dismay Among the Survivors

body: There was the Summer of Sam and the summer of the West Nile virus, summers when blackouts, racial unrest, heat waves, crime waves or, yes, rampant pit bull attacks defined the season. title: The Summer of ... You Tell Me

body: In April, when word reached Crown Heights that New York City's homeless services agency planned to move its central intake center from Manhattan to the Bedford-Atlantic Armory in Brooklyn, local residents started a fierce campaign to prevent the move. title: Concessions Made in Plan For Homeless In Brooklyn

title: 2 Neighborhood Teenagers Surrender in Brooklyn Boy's Shooting

title: After a Boy's Shooting, 'Why?' Is on Everyone's Lips

body: MY rainwater collection tour started one morning last week with a cup plant, Silphium perfoliatum, in Lenny Librizzi's front garden on Staten Island. This prairie plant's daisy-like flowers bloomed way over our heads, and its oval leaves joined at the stem like big hands, cupping about half an inch of the rain that had fallen the night before.
title: IN THE GARDEN; Raindrops Keep Falling In My Tank

body: People who hazard the No. 4 subway line each day don't need the numbers to tell them: It's slow. Not just slow, it turns out, but of the city's two dozen or so subway lines, its on-time performance is the poorest and getting worse, according to new statistics released on Monday by New York City Transit. The figures were among a raft of dismal
title: Subway Delays Rise, and the No. 4 Line Is the Biggest Laggard

body: FOR CHILDREN 'CINDERELLA' She doesn't lose her mother. She doesn't lose a glass slipper. She doesn't even lose her dignity: no rags, no chores, no sleeping in the fireplace ashes. title: Spare Times: For Children

title: Adopting an Open-Door Policy With His Constituents, but Passing on the Doors

title: New Vision For Schools Proposes Broad Role

title: Restless Pioneers, Seeding Brooklyn

body: The 11:30 a.m. service at Grace Tabernacle Christian Center in Brooklyn seemed like most others there. Sunday school had just let out, and the parade of white-brimmed hats began to fill the pews. The artificial shrubs were dusted off and the maroon recliners moved into place. The cymbals crashed, and the churchgoers began to dance and sing
title: Church Shaken by Crash That Took Pastor's Kin

body: A Brooklyn pastor and acclaimed gospel singer was critically injured and his wife was killed when their vehicle was hit head-on by a car that was headed the wrong way on a Pennsylvania highway, the authorities said. The Rev. Timothy Wright, 61, founder and pastor of Grace Tabernacle Christian Center in Crown Heights, was in critical condition late
title: Car Crash Badly Hurts Gospel Star; Wife Dies

body: Childhood lead poisoning declined by 15 percent last year, the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene reported on Wednesday, reaching the lowest rate ever recorded in New York City. The 2007 figure -- 1,970 poisonings among children 6 months to 6 years of age -- is a 90 percent decline since 1995, when nearly 20,000 children were identified with
title: Lead Poisoning Cases Decline

body: The state comptroller, Thomas P. DiNapoli, said on Wednesday that his office had uncovered numerous instances of child care centers in New York City misspending public funds. He said his office had referred 19 child care centers to local prosecutors for possible criminal investigation. At a news conference in Manhattan, Mr. DiNapoli announced the
title: State Finds Fund Misuse At 19 Child Care Centers

body: Four teenagers have been arrested on hate crime charges for throwing rocks at a school bus full of Jewish toddlers in a Brooklyn neighborhood with a volatile racial history, the police said on Friday. The police said that three girls and one boy yelled epithets as they broke windows on the bus in Crown Heights last month. The children in the bus
title: 4 Accused of Hate Crime

author: E-mail: susan.dominus@nytimes.com
body: Moments before Yosef Abrahamson, 16, accepted an award for the essay he'd written in a competition sponsored by the Police Athletic League, an officer approached him to complain about his fedora. The hat, an essential wardrobe item for Hasidic men, was gaudy, the policeman told him, and what's with all these kids today and their nose rings and
title: BIG CITY; Young Man From Omaha May Be Perfect As Brooklynite

body: INTERNATIONAL NO RUSHING TALKS ON PACT With U.S., Iraqis Say Discussions among Iraqi politicians on the country's long-term security agreement with the United States are under way, but it may take months before the agreement is completed. American officials would like a deal before the Democratic and Republican national conventions. But for Iraqis,
title: INSIDE THE TIMES: June 16, 2008

body: FOR years, ''I was the loser who lived at home,'' Ezra Wine said. Mr. Wine, now 27, says he remained at home with his parents in their SoHo loft even as his elder brother, Jonah, moved to Chicago ''because he couldn't deal with New York, rent-wise,'' and even as his friends began ''paying $2,000 for studio apartments downtown.'' The family's
title: THE HUNT; Tunnel Vision

body: An investigation into a rash of arsons two years ago in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, helped prosecutors uncover a different crime in the neighborhood: mortgage fraud. On Feb. 24, 2006, officials were investigating a possible link between two suspicious fires on neighboring blocks, one at 1033 Pacific Street in which four people died and another, barely
title: Mortgage Fraud Is Found During Fire Investigation

body: With grocery bags in his hands, Jose Figueroa stood on a hill above the politicians as they announced an agreement on Monday that would keep his rent at the sprawling Starrett City residential complex in Brooklyn affordable for years to come. During the last year, in nervous conversations in elevators or at the supermarket, Mr. Figueroa and other
title: Starrett City Residents Breathe Easier With the Announcement of Sale Terms

body: A worker who was power-washing the upper facade of an apartment building in Brooklyn without wearing a safety harness died on Monday after he fell four stories to the ground, officials said. The victim was identified by friends as Houssain Mosharrf, who turned 50 on Sunday. Investigators at the scene said they had not yet determined what caused Mr.
title: Building Washer Falls 4 Stories to His Death in Brooklyn; Officials Cite Safety Omissions

body: IN mid-April, a young black man in Crown Heights was struck with a baton and sprayed with Mace by two white men, according to the police, and ever since, tensions have run high in the Brooklyn neighborhood. Jews and blacks who live there eye one another warily, and police patrols and surveillance have intensified. But there is another split on
title: CROWN HEIGHTS; Patrolling The Streets, And Dissing The Rivals

body: There are neighborhoods in the far reaches of New York City, from Tottenville on Staten Island to Bushwick in Brooklyn, that have about as much in common with the glimmering, candy-coated Manolo Blahnik world of ''Sex and the City'' as, say, East Texas. As the film version of the popular television series opens on Friday, it is easy to imagine that
title: Far From the Glamour, Identifying With 4 Fabulous Friends

body: The Homeless Go to a Place They Know To the Editor: Re ''Doors Close, Doors Open, and the Homeless Trudge On'' (Dispatches, May 18), about a plan to move the city's main intake center for homeless men from the former Bellevue Psychiatric Hospital to the Bedford-Atlantic Armory in Crown Heights, Brooklyn: As a clinician who has worked with homeless
title: LETTERS; Seeking Solutions For People Adrift

Hynes on accusations that Shmira, a Hasidic civilian patrol group, has been uncooperative with investigators. His comment, ''You
title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD

body: Two teenagers were arrested on Thursday in an attack on an Orthodox Jewish teenager in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, one of several recent cases that have stirred tensions between black and Jewish residents in a neighborhood with a volatile racial history. Namor Clarke, 17, of Clinton Hill, and a 14-year-old whose name was withheld by the police were
title: Two Are Charged in Attack on Teenager in Crown Heights

body: The streets of Crown Heights, Brooklyn, resembled an armed camp on Wednesday. On Albany Avenue, near where a black man was assaulted by Hasidic Jews last month, police officers milled around a mobile command center. Two blocks farther down Albany, at the corner where a Jewish teenager was robbed and beaten by black youths last week, an officer
title: CROWN HEIGHTS JOURNAL; Police Are Out in Force as a Neighborhood Simmers With Tension Again

body: When Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg stood at City Hall two years ago to announce that he had just filed suit against several gun shop owners, mainly in the South, it was in a certain fashion the capstone of a signature campaign. Mr. Bloomberg had already bashed the industry in several angry speeches, gone to Washington to pressure congressmen and
title: Gun Dealer and Mayor Face Showdown

body: INTERNATIONAL DIPLOMATIC INITIATIVE SEEKS Talks for Abkhazia Tensions The long military standoff in Abkhazia has entered a phase of quiet diplomacy intended to ease tensions and push for negotiations, officials on each side of the conflict said. An act of significant violence or other provocation could still lead to war, leaders cautioned, but an
title: INSIDE THE TIMES: May 22, 2008

body: THE old brick building that sits behind a tall iron fence at East 30th Street and First Avenue has been a haven for the lost since 1931. From that year until 1984 it operated as Bellevue Psychiatric Hospital, and now its ivy-covered walls house some 600 homeless men, along with the main intake center for homeless men citywide. Soon, the building
title: DISPATCHES; Doors Close, Doors Open, and the Homeless Trudge On

body: A crowd of more than 300 Hasidic Jews, some shouting ''We want justice!'' marched in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, on Friday afternoon to protest the assault and robbery of a Jewish teenager early that morning. The protesters marched from the scene of the assault, at Empire Boulevard and Albany Avenue, to the 71st Precinct station, and then up New York
title: Hasidic Crowd Protests Attack

body: The body of a woman who had been slashed to death was discovered on Monday on a Brooklyn street, about 30 feet from her car, and her 1-year-old son was found unharmed in the car, the police said. The woman, identified as Iasha Bristol, 27, of Bedford-Stuyvesant, had been slashed across the throat, the police said. Her body was found by a passer-by
title: Woman, 27, Found Dead On a Street In Brooklyn

body: One man was slashed to death in Queens and another was fatally shot in Brooklyn in two unrelated cases on Saturday, the police said. One man, identified as Henry Frasier, 40, was cut with a razor and killed late Saturday night in a fight with a neighbor outside his cousin's home in Queens, the police said. The fight took place shortly before 10
title: 2 Men Are Killed in Separate Cases in Queens and Brooklyn

body: A neighbor of a Brooklyn man who was fatally shot in his apartment building said on Saturday that the victim had received a cellphone call just before the shooting, and the police said that robbery did not appear to have been a motive. The police and neighbors also said that two people had been seen running from the building right after the
title: Call Comes, Then a Man Is Shot Dead In Brooklyn

body: $2.15 MILLION 1492-1494 St. Johns Place Crown Heights, Brooklyn The Cathedral School, an Anglican day school now in Park Slope, is renovating this two-story 9,600-square-foot 1925 building, formerly a Jewish day school. It plans to move in June. Buyer: People's Cathedral of Brooklyn Seller: Benshirl Realty Corp. Broker: Michael H. Rothstein, Marcus
title: TRANSACTIONS; Recent Sale

body: They found the remains of Firefighter Jimmy Riches in the rubble of the World Trade Center on March 25, 2002. A brother, Tom Riches, then just 17, walked down into the pit, and he and his father and his other two brothers carried Jimmy out on a stretcher. On Sunday morning, six years later, Tom Riches walked once again into the hole. There, about
title: In the Pit, With the Pope and Memories of a Brother

body: As detectives in Brooklyn continued their investigation into the assault of a black man in Crown Heights by two white men, community leaders and others asked residents on Friday to step forward to help the police solve the case. The victim, Andrew Charles, 20, the son of a New York City police officer, was walking with a black friend about 6:30
title: Residents' Help Sought After Man Is Beaten in Crown Heights

body: A caption on April 8 with a picture in some editions showing Brooklyn third graders working on a ''School Is Cool'' mural misidentified the school that the children attend. It is Public School 335 in Crown Heights, Brooklyn -- not P.S. 35.
title: Corrections: For the Record

body: Paul Lacy, 50, has lived in Brooklyn for all but two years since 1983. He has worked as a night watchman and an apprentice furniture maker. Now he does freelance page layout for publishers of science and technical books. But Mr. Lacy's real passion -- like that of so many New Yorkers who are defined as much by their hobbies as their day jobs -- is
title: CITY ROOM; Storefronts as Metaphor for a Changing Borough

body: Correction: April 16, 2008, Wednesday A caption on April 8 with a picture in some editions showing Brooklyn third graders working on a ''School Is Cool'' mural misidentified the school that the children attend. It is Public School 335 in Crown Heights, Brooklyn -- not P.S. 35.
title: ON THE STREET, A POSITIVE MESSAGE ABOUT SCHOOL

body: Ten years ago, Denise de las Nueces was a nerdy high school student from a poor Manhattan neighborhood, poring over astronomy books her father had picked out of the trash at the building where he worked as a doorman. Eight years ago, Letica Fox-Thomas was finishing up a childhood spent partly in the city's homeless shelters while cramming for her
title: For Times Scholars, School Was One of Many Hurdles

body: Randi Weingarten has spent more than a decade cultivating a reputation as the archetypal union leader: a combative dealmaker and consummate political street fighter for city teachers. Yet at a recent education conference in Nashville, there was a fellow from the conservative Hoover Institute, Eric A. Hanushek, gushing with praise for Ms.
title: A Schools Veteran Girds for a Broader Battlefield

body: It was in the opening days of the trial of three detectives in Queens, and Anthony L. Ricco, a lawyer for the undercover detective who fired the first shots of a barrage that killed Sean Bell, was on his way to lunch when the question came. ''A bunch of young people ran up behind me quickly,'' Mr. Ricco recalled. They wore pins for the New Black
title: Defending Detective, Lawyer Feels the Heat

body: FOR a tutorial on the complex set of factors driving up the price of a quart of milk, a good person to talk to is Modesto Baez, a Dominican who is the proprietor of the Quisqueya Super Market at Franklin Avenue and Eastern Parkway in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. The offerings at Mr. Baez's bodega, in a heavily West Indian neighborhood, include plantain
title: CROWN HEIGHTS; Trickle-Down Economics In the Dairy Section

body: Let us grant -- just for the sake of argument -- that the idea that ''boys and girls learn differently'' has some kind of truth attached to it (Elizabeth Weil, March 2). In all other things, we praise diversity in the classroom. Should boys not be exposed to the experience of girls learning differently, and vice versa? And how are boys and girls to
title: Letters: Teaching to the Testosterone

body: TAKE the D train to 55th Street in central Brooklyn, and you feel as if you have set foot in a different world. The station sits at the junction of New Utrecht Avenue, 13th Avenue and 55th Street in the heart of Borough Park, home to a quarter-million Orthodox Jews, one of the largest concentrations of Jews outside Israel. To travel to Borough Park
title: THE CITY VISIBLE; In the Land Of Black Coats

author: Elizabeth Weil is a contributing writer for the magazine. Her most recent article was about when a child should start kindergarten.
body: On an unseasonably cold day last November in Foley, Ala., Colby Royster and Michael Peterson, two students in William Bender's fourth-grade public-school class, informed me that the class corn snake could eat a rat faster than the class boa constrictor. Bender teaches 26 fourth graders, all boys. Down the hall and around the corner, Michelle Gay
title: Teaching to the Testosterone

body: The butter-hued building with porthole windows rises from the weathered brownstones of Crown Heights like a yellow submarine surfacing from a slate-gray sea. The Brooklyn Children's Museum, after a six-year, $46 million expansion complicated by financial challenges, is readying itself to open in May. On a recent afternoon Rafael Viñoly, the
title: A Serious Building, Tailor Made for Fun

body: In the smoky caldron of a high-rise fire, it is the firefighter's worst nightmare: a door left ajar, a window that suddenly breaks under intense heat and a blast of wind. At its worst, the outcome is catastrophic. Known to firefighters as a blowtorch effect, the instant combination of fire and wind can blast fireballs across rooms and down
title: Tackling Challenges of High-Rise Blazes, Fire Officials Go to the Laboratory

body: Junior High School 22, in the South Bronx, had run through six principals in just over two years when Shimon Waronker was named the seventh. On his first visit, in October 2004, he found a police officer arresting a student and calling for backup to handle the swelling crowd. Students roamed the hallways with abandon; in one class of 30, only 5
title: In Bronx School, Culture Shock, Then Revival

body: JACOB GOLDSTEIN, the longtime chairman of Community Board 9 and the unofficial mayor of Crown Heights, Brooklyn, was driving his little red Ford Contour through the neighborhood the other day, honking at acquaintances. Several times on every block, he braked and gestured at a newly risen, salmon-colored apartment building, or a plywood fence
title: CROWN HEIGHTS; Here Come the Babies. There Go the Jackhammers.

author: E-mail: fyi@nytimes.com
body: Dibs on a Junker Q. There's an older BMW parked near my home in Jackson Heights, Queens, that has clearly been abandoned. It's been there for more than a month and it is accumulating parking tickets. Is there any legal way for someone to claim it as one's own? A. Sorry. You can legally take possession of an abandoned sofa, but not a BMW. The
title: F. Y. I.

author: E-mail: susan.dominus@nytimes.com
body: Derrick Braxton has six fingers on his left hand, but that's only one of the reasons he had a circle of fascinated students gathered around him one day early in his first semester at college. A freshman at Finger Lakes Community College in Canandaigua, N.Y., Mr. Braxton was eating a salami and cheese sandwich in the school lounge last fall when a
title: BIG CITY; Stranger in a Strange Land Earns Himself an Encore

body: ANYONE who has seen one of Anna Deavere Smith's full-length theater works -- ''Fires in the Mirror'' or ''Twilight: Los Angeles, 1992'' -- will have some idea of what to expect at ''Let Me Down Easy, '' at Long Wharf through Feb. 3. For everyone else, a bit of an introduction is in order. But that's a problem. Ms. Smith wears so many hats -- and
title: THEATER | NEW HAVEN; The Multiple Faces Of Anna Deavere Smith

author: E-mail: susan.dominus@nytimes.com
body: The subway in New York is a high-speed tour of the best and worst the city has to offer, a fast-moving showcase of surprising civility, but also, occasionally, unnerving cruelty. At those times, the commute home feels like a test: A woman across the car is shaking her child, shaking him hard enough that it hurts just to watch, but who's to say what
title: BIG CITY; Hard Days Behind Her, She Helps Families With Theirs

body: The four-story red-brick building blends in with the apartment houses on a hardscrabble stretch of hair salons and liquor stores in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. But it is here, miles from what was not long ago the most notorious skid row in America, where a new kind of Bowery makes its home. The building, an eight-unit residential property at 69
title: Illegal Boarding Houses Pit City's Laws Against Lack of Alternatives

body: Anna Deavere Smith covers a big patch of territory in ''Let Me Down Easy,'' her populous new solo show at the Long Wharf Theater here. A checklist of topics covered would include the steroid scandal in sports, cancer therapies, African folk healing, the genocide in Rwanda, the tragedy of Katrina and the ailing American health-care system. Oh, and
title: THEATER REVIEW | 'LET ME DOWN EASY'; The Body of Her Work: Hearing Questions of Life and Death

body: AS usual, Mendy Pellin wore the traditional black coat and hat of a Hasid and sat on a high stool facing the camera. He read quickly through a page of notes, shook his head vigorously in the way of preparation, and signaled his readiness with a nod to his cameraman, Dovi Trappler. As the camera rolled, Mr. Pellin's voice dropped to the confident
title: CROWN HEIGHTS; Comedy Central, By Way Of the Torah

body: ''The littlest things you do in people's lives that, you don't know, it changes their whole life,'' Iman Thomas said. This spring, Ms. Thomas, 31, will discover if a grant from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, coupled with her own determination, can change her life and the lives of her three children. In March, she will complete a
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Getting Help to Enable Herself to Help Others

body: New York residents are being hit with an unusual combination this week: unseasonably warm weather and maddeningly large heating bills. After receiving a bill for nearly $1,200 on Monday, Maxine Simpson turned off her hot-water heater to conserve oil. Ms. Simpson said that she had been taking just 100 gallons at a time from her dealer -- enough to
title: New Yorkers Paying More Than Ever to Keep Their Homes Warm This Winter

body: By the time thousands of mourners gathered on Tuesday to say farewell to Lt. John H. Martinson, his fellow firefighters had already spent five days telling the world about his bravery, his willingness to run first into the flames and stay there until everyone had escaped, which is part of what led to his death last week at a smoky Brooklyn blaze.
title: Tributes and Grief at a Funeral for a Firefighter

body: It has been 50 years since the Brooklyn Dodgers played their last game at Ebbets Field on Sept. 24, 1957. For residents of the Ebbets Field Apartments -- the high-rise housing complex erected at the site of the ballpark in Crown Heights -- 50 years can seem like ancient history. The teenagers talk basketball, not baseball. One tenant says he thinks
title: Where Once Brooklyn Triumphed, a Tragic Scene

body: Beneath the freshly hung black- and-purple bunting on Engine Company 249's firehouse in Brooklyn on Friday morning, the firefighters' commanding officer summed up the department's latest loss in six words. ''John Martinson went in first, always,'' Capt. Thomas Reilly said. Lieutenant Martinson was, indeed, the first firefighter into the
title: To Friends and Family, A Fallen Firefighter Was 'Johnny Nice Guy'

body: A Brooklyn strip club bouncer and martial arts enthusiast who had said he was framed by police assassins was sentenced to 50 years to life in prison on Thursday for the murders of two men in 2005. The bouncer, Stephen Sakai, 32, was dealt the maximum sentence by Justice John P. Walsh of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, but not before introducing
title: Brooklyn Bouncer Gets 50 Years to Life for 2 Murders
